section:
Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier Class Reference Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier
(2024-06-08) I belive there are too many ways to edit a text editor. There should only be 'Insert(...)' and 'Remove(...)' methods. Any code I currently have in 'TextEditorModelModifier.cs' that I deem as technical debt or a bad idea will be put in this file. Then, once organized I hope to make sense of what the "lean" solution is.

Static Public Attributes
const int MINIMUM_PARTITION_SIZE = 4
__SplitIntoTwoPartitions(int) will divide by 2 and give the first split the remainder, then add 1 to the first split if there is a multibyte scenario. Therefore partition size of 3 would infinitely try to split itself.
Properties
RichCharacter[] RichCharacterList [get]
ImmutableList< TextEditorPartition > PartitionList [get]
IList< ITextEditorEdit > EditBlockList [get]
IList< LineEnd > LineEndList [get]
Convert an index for a LineEnd to a LineInformation, use the method: TextEditorModelExtensionMethods.GetLineInformation(ITextEditorModel, int).
IList<(LineEndKind lineEndKind, int count)> LineEndKindCountList [get]
IList< TextEditorPresentationModel > PresentationModelList [get]
IList< int > TabKeyPositionList [get]
Provides exact position index of a tab character.
LineEndKind? OnlyLineEndKind [get]
If there is a mixture of-Carriage Return-Linefeed-CRLF Then this will be null. If there are no line endings then this will be null.
LineEndKind LineEndKindPreference [get]
ResourceUri ResourceUri [get]
TODO: On (2023-10-02) Key<TextEditorModel> was removed, because it felt redundant... ...given only 1 TextEditorModel can exist for a given ResourceUri. This change however creates an issue regarding 'fake' resource uri's that are used for in-memory files. For example, Options.Displays.TextEditorSettingsPreview now has the resource URI of "__LUTHETUS_SETTINGS_PREVIEW__". This is an issue because could a user have on their filesystem the file "__LUTHETUS_SETTINGS_PREVIEW__"? (at that exact resource uri).
DateTime ResourceLastWriteTime [get]
string FileExtension [get]
This is displayed within theDisplays.Internals.TextEditorFooter.
IDecorationMapper DecorationMapper [get]

bool IsDirty [get]

int LineCount [get]
int PreviousLineCount [get]
int CharCount [get]
Stack< TextEditorEditOther > OtherEditStack = new() [get]
The TextEditorEditOther works by invoking 'Open' then when finished invoking 'Close'.
bool WasDirty [get]
This property optimizes the dirty state tracking. If _wasDirty != _isDirty then track the state change. This involves writing to dependency injectable state, then triggering a re-render in the Edits.Displays.DirtyResourceUriInteractiveIconDisplay.
bool WasModified [get, set]
This property decides whether or not to replace the existing model in IState<TextEditorState> with the instance that comes from this modifier.
bool ShouldReloadVirtualizationResult [get, set]
This property decides whether or not to re-calculate the virtualization result that gets displayed on the UI.
string AllText [get]
Detailed Description
(2024-06-08) I belive there are too many ways to edit a text editor. There should only be 'Insert(...)' and 'Remove(...)' methods. Any code I currently have in 'TextEditorModelModifier.cs' that I deem as technical debt or a bad idea will be put in this file. Then, once organized I hope to make sense of what the "lean" solution is.
(2024-06-08) I've been dogfooding the IDE, and the 'TextEditorModelModifier.cs' file demonstrates some clear issues regarding text editor optimization. Im breaking up the 80,000 character file a bit here into partial classes for now. TODO: merge the partial classes back?
Any modified state needs to be 'null coallesce assigned' to the existing TextEditorModel's value.
When reading state, if the state had been 'null coallesce assigned' then the field will be read. Otherwise, the existing TextEditorModel's value will be read.

Delete() DeleteLuthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifierDelete
void Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier.Delete (CursorModifierBagTextEditor cursorModifierBag, int columnCount, bool expandWord, DeleteKind deleteKind, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default , bool shouldCreateEditHistory = true )
This method allows for a "RemoveRange" like operation on the text editor's contents. Any meta-data will automatically be updated (e.g. ITextEditorModel.LineEndKindCountList.
Parameters
cursorModifierBag
The list of cursors that indicate the positionIndex to start a "RemoveRange" operation. The cursors are iterated backwards, with each cursor being its own "RemoveRange" operation.
columnCount
The amount of columns to delete. If a the value of a column is of 2-char length (e.g. "\r\n"), then internally this columnCount will be converted to a 'charCount' of the corrected length.
expandWord
Applied after moving by the 'count' parameter. Ex: count of 1, and expandWord of true; will move 1 char-value from the initialPositionIndex. Afterwards, if expandWord is true, then the cursor is checked to be within a word, or at the start or end of one. If the cursor is at the start or end of one, then the selection to delete is expanded such that it contains the entire word that the cursor ended at.
cancellationToken
deleteKind
The default DeleteKind.Delete will do logic similar to a "RemoveRange" like operation on a collection type. If one has keyboard input from a user, one might want to have the user's backspace key pass in the DeleteKind.Backspace parameter. Then, for a user's delete key, pass in DeleteKind.Delete.

TODO: On (2023-10-02) Key<TextEditorModel> was removed, because it felt redundant... ...given only 1 TextEditorModel can exist for a given ResourceUri. This change however creates an issue regarding 'fake' resource uri's that are used for in-memory files. For example, Options.Displays.TextEditorSettingsPreview now has the resource URI of "__LUTHETUS_SETTINGS_PREVIEW__". This is an issue because could a user have on their filesystem the file "__LUTHETUS_SETTINGS_PREVIEW__"? (at that exact resource uri).

Definition at line 58 of file TextEditorModelModifier.Main.cs.
RichCharacterList RichCharacterListLuthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifierRichCharacterList
RichCharacter [] Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.TextEditorModelModifier.RichCharacterList[get]
Changed this property to an array from an ImmutableList (2024-08-13).
The motivation for this change comes from calculating the virtualization result.
The storage for the underlying data of a 'ImmutableList' is believed to be more of a 'tree' structure than a contiguous array.
And therefore, when we virtualize vertically, and then horizontally after, this is an incredible amount of overhead if performed on a 'tree'-like structure.
A contiguous array is expected to be a dramatic improvement in performance when calculating the virtualization result.
A side note on this change: could .NET internally more easily leverage caching with this now being a contiguous array, rather than a 'tree'?
A worry: I'm not quite certain on the details of the idea in my head. It is something along lines of an array being treated as a struct and that this could cause a mess somehow? | Copying the entire list of rich characters versus just passing around a pointer kind of thing. | But, this array is located on an object, the text editor model, and it is the model that is being passed around in the code base. So this shouldn't be an issue.
Quite non-scientifically I simply took note of the memory usage that the Task Manager on windows reported for the IDE while this used to be an ImmutableList, before I made the change. | It was 1,744 MB of memory pre change. It is 1,568 MB of memory after change.
There is 0 control of variables going on here so the change of 200 MB perhaps is completely meaningless.
More so, I took a simple note of memory usage incase I see that the memory usage doubled or something absurd.
Would the app's memory go up, or would the so called ".NET Host" have its memory go up? I'm seeing in task manager a process called ".NET Host", separate to that of "Luthetus.Ide.Photino".
I'm now seeing 643 MB of memory usage after changing RichCharacter to a struct from a class
